ygData.messageBody:
Right, the 'chase' range is the distance you need to get between you and a
mob before it will give up chasing you. As I'm sure we've all seen this can
be enormously greater than the agro range. By the time the mob does wonder
within this range, you've pulsed on your group so many times that you are
way up there hate list wise.

Kit

-----Original Message-----
From: Daniel P. Sniderman [mailto:fuzzbone@...]
Sent: Friday, January 26, 2001 1:24 PM
To: eqbards@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [eqbards] My first experience with Bard aggro....


I believe so - I've heard anecdotal reports of other classes getting this
but its much rarer.

A possible explanation - I think the hate range is greater than agro - so
mobs can add you to your hate range that you never fight. We are pulsing a
6x buff to our parties in downtime - where as other classes that buff are
doing it once every so often - so the odds are less that they'll get on a
hate list - and will be on fewer hate lists.

Slyde

Subject: RE: [eqbards] My first experience with Bard aggro....


Out of curiousity, do DOTs work this way too? That is, if a shaman I'm
grouped with hit's something with a DOT and the bugger runs off, spreading
the hate, and the shaman camps out, do I get on the hate list for having
been grouped with the shaman? Does the shaman get back on the hate list if
he then heals me?


Unrelated question: I've been invited to a Dalnir raid on the condition
that I can get into the high teens by February 3rd (oh how I laughed!).
Should hell freeze over and I make three or four levels in the next week,
is Dalnir's still going to be insanely difficult for me?

This is a multi-group raid and I'd be in the lowest level group - a full
group of low-teens/early-twenties.

Evulia, 14.8 levels and crawling, Tunare
